query: Can you show me a bar chart of the percentiles of the different areas of deforestation?

nodes.label: anthropogenic climate change
nodes.description: that human activity (e.g. burning fossil fuels such as coal, oil, and natural gas) is the dominant driver of the current changes to the climate and the environment

nodes.label: trade sector
nodes.description: This sector involves the wholesale and retail selling of goods.

nodes.label: sustainable development goal 2
nodes.description: SDG2: zero hunger

nodes.label: timber production
nodes.description: activities involved in harvesting, processing, and distributing wood and wood-based products for construction, paper production, and other uses

nodes.label: SDG target 2.b
nodes.description: Correct and prevent trade restrictions and distortions in world agricultural markets, including through the parallel elimination of all forms of agricultural export subsidies and all export measures with equivalent effect

nodes.label: health policy
nodes.description: development, implementation, and evaluation of policies, regulations, and frameworks to improve healthcare systems

nodes.label: preventive healthcare
nodes.description: Services and initiatives aimed at preventing diseases and promoting health through public awareness programs

nodes.label: private healthcare sector
nodes.description: The segment of the healthcare system provided by private actors. Includes services through private hospitals, clinics, and practitioners

nodes.label: land degradation
nodes.description: A negative trend in the condition of land, expressed as long-term reduction or loss of at least one of the following: biological productivity, ecological integrity or value to humans.

nodes.label: welfare activities
nodes.description: Support services provided by a range of actors, including but not limited to the state.

nodes.label: salinization
nodes.description: Increasing evaporation from rising temperatures leads to the salinization of soil and water. Salts accumulate in the soils of arid environments.

nodes.label: plastic leaching
nodes.description: The process of when plastic elements contaminate its surrounding environment.

nodes.label: health insurance
nodes.description: Financial products designed to cover the cost of medical expenses, including hospitalization, doctor visits, and preventive care

nodes.label: water supply management
nodes.description: planning, regulation, and maintenance of water supply systems to provide safe and clean water for residential, industrial, and agricultural use

nodes.label: wildfire
nodes.description: Wildfires are any unplanned or uncontrolled fire affecting natural, cultural, industrial and residential landscapes. Changing weather conditions associated with global warming increase the probability of wildfires.

nodes.label: public sanitation services management
nodes.description: Oversight of public sanitation systems, including sewage, wastewater treatment, and hygiene infrastructure, to promote public health and safety

nodes.label: deforestation
nodes.description: Removal of forest and conversion of the land to non-forest use, and is the direct human-induced conversion of forested land to non-forested land

nodes.label: undifferentiated goods- and services-producing activities of private households for own use
health rehabilitation service
nodes.description: Healthcare services aimed at restoring physical, mental, or social function after injury, illness, or surgery

nodes.label: crop production
nodes.description: This area encompasses the cultivation of plants for food, feed, fibree, fuel, and other purposes. It involves activities like planting, growing, and harvesting a wide variety of crops.

nodes.label: forestry
nodes.description: science and craft of creating, managing, using, conserving and repairing forests, woodlands, and associated resources for human and environmental benefits

nodes.label: ocean acidification
nodes.description: Ocean acidification refers to a reduction in the pH of the ocean over an extended period of time, caused primarily by uptake of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere.

nodes.label: forest
nodes.description: A dense collection of trees covering a relatively large area

nodes.label: slow onset events
nodes.description: Slow onset events evolve gradually from incremental changes over many years or from increased frequency or intensity of recurring events. As defined in the Cancun Adaptation Framework (2010), slow onset events include risks and impacts from rising temperatures, desertification, biodiversity loss, land and forest degradation, glacial retreat, ocean acidification, sea level rise, and salinization.

nodes.label: rural poor
nodes.description: people living outside of urban areas with limited assets or access to services

nodes.label: flood
nodes.description: Floods are the inundation of normally dry land, resulting from a mix of hydrology, climate, and human factors, varying by type and region.

nodes.label: agriculture sector
nodes.description: Activities that involve the cultivation of crops and raising of livestock for food, fibre, and other products essential for human life and industry.

nodes.label: terrestrial risk
nodes.description: Terrestrial means "of the earth" and relates to the ecological system that includes all living organisms and their interactions within land-based environments, such as forests, grasslands, and deserts.

nodes.label: rainwater harvesting
nodes.description: Rainwater harvesting is defined as a method for inducing, collecting, storing and conserving local surface runoff for agriculture in arid and semi-arid regions.  Both small and large scale structures are used for rainwater harvesting collection and storage including tanks, reservoirs and dams.

nodes.label: marine risk
nodes.description: Risks to the ecosystem health of the marine environment, including ocean warming, ocean acidification, and ocean deoxygenation, harming biodiversity, species health, ecosystem services, and coastal community livelihoods.

nodes.label: e-commerce
nodes.description: Buying and selling of goods and services over the internet, facilitated through digital platforms

nodes.label: biodiversity
nodes.description: The variability among living organisms from all sources and the ecological complexes of which they are part.

nodes.label: drought
nodes.description: A drought is an extended period of unusually dry weather marked by a significant and sustained lack of precipitation, falling below a specific threshold over a large area for more than a month

nodes.label: trade institution
nodes.description: Organisation or entity that facilitates, regulates, or supports trade activities

nodes.label: soil erosion
nodes.description: Soil erosion is defined as the accelerated removal of topsoil from the land surface through water, wind and tillage

nodes.label: forest degradation
nodes.description: Land degradation in forested areas, referring to the loss of the biological wealth of a forest.

nodes.label: fish processing
nodes.description: post-harvest handling, processing, packaging, and distribution of fish and seafood products to consumers and markets

nodes.label: sanitation
nodes.description: Provision of facilities and services for management and the safe disposal of waste water

nodes.label: sea level rise
nodes.description: Sea level rise is a change to the height of sea level, both globally and locally at seasonal, annual, or longer time scales due to change in ocean volume.

nodes.label: pesticide
nodes.description: Pesticide means any substance, or mixture of substances of chemical or biological ingredients intended for repelling, destroying or controlling any pest, or regulating plant growth. Pesticides are inherently toxic.

nodes.label: extreme weather
nodes.description: Extreme weather refers to events where a weather variable exceeds (or falls below) a threshold. Meaning it is significantly different from the average or usual weather pattern.

nodes.label: water insecurity
nodes.description: Water scarcity can be defined as a lack of sufficient water, or not having access to safe water supplies.

nodes.label: informal sector
nodes.description: Households employing domestic workers, for activities like cooking, cleaning and subsistence farming, for their own use.

nodes.label: international trade
nodes.description: Exchange of goods and services across national borders, encompassing imports and exports

nodes.label: stormwater management
nodes.description: Management of rainwater runoff to minimize flooding, erosion, and water pollution, often through the use of drainage systems

nodes.label: heavy fuel oil
nodes.description: HFO is used for the large ship engines of cargo vessels, cruise ships and other similar vehicles.

nodes.label: water collection system
nodes.description: collection and storage of rainwater that would otherwise flow down gutters into the drain

nodes.label: recreational fishing
nodes.description: fishing for pleasure or sport, not primarily for commercial gain or subsistence

nodes.label: adaptation
nodes.description: The process of adjusting to living in a changing climate. This can include altering behaviour, systems, and ways of life to reduce or avoid both current and future harms from climate impacts.

nodes.label: forestry sector
nodes.description: Activities that relate to the production of goods and services from forests.

nodes.label: healthcare sector
nodes.description: This sector provides medical services, manufactures medical equipment, and develops pharmaceuticals to maintain and improve health.

nodes.label: tertiary healthcare
nodes.description: Advanced medical care involving highly specialised treatments, complex surgeries, and cutting-edge technologies, usually provided in specialised facilities

nodes.label: green trade
nodes.description: Exchange of goods and services that promote environmental sustainability and reduce ecological impact

nodes.label: desertification
nodes.description: Land degradation in arid, semi-arid and dry sub-humid areas (drylands) resulting from various factors, including climatic variations and human activities.

nodes.label: commercial fishing
nodes.description: capture of wild fish and other seafood for commercial profit, primarily supplying the global food market

nodes.label: coral bleaching
nodes.description: Coral bleaching occurs when corals expel the algae living in their tissues, usually due to increased sea temperatures, leaving them white and more susceptible to disease.

nodes.label: fishing sector
nodes.description: Activities involving the catching, processing, and selling of fish for food, recreation, and industry.

nodes.label: utility services management
nodes.description: oversight of public utilities such as water supply, electricity, waste management, and sanitation to ensure reliable service delivery.

nodes.label: mental health service
nodes.description: Healthcare services focused on the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of mental health conditions and emotional well-being

nodes.label: increasing temperatures
nodes.description: Earth's temperature has risen since 1850 due to human induced climate change. Increasing temperatures intensify the hydrologic cycle, causing dry regions to become drier and wet regions to become wetter.

nodes.label: invasive species
nodes.description: Invasive species, or alien invasive species, are non-native species that threaten ecosystems, habitats, and other species, causing social, economic, environmental, or health harm.

nodes.label: Reduced impact logging
nodes.description: Logging techniques that result in significantly less damage to the surrounding forest and forest ecosystem. Examples of RIL include directional felling, trimming of inter-crown vines, and careful road planning.

nodes.label: agricultural water management
nodes.description: planning and operation of water systems to supply water for agricultural purposes, including irrigation and livestock needs

nodes.label: activities of households as employers of domestic personnel
water quality monitoring
nodes.description: activities aimed at maintaining and improving water quality by monitoring pollutants

nodes.label: integrated water resources management
nodes.description: A holistic approach to managing water resources that balances social, economic, and environmental needs

nodes.label: primary healthcare system
nodes.description: Basic or general health services provided as the first point of contact for individuals, focusing on prevention, wellness, and common illnesses

nodes.label: animal production
nodes.description: Animal production involves raising livestock for meat, milk, eggs, wool, hides, and other animal products.

nodes.label: food and beverage service activities
nodes.description: Preparation, presentation, and serving of meals, snacks, and beverages to customers in settings such as restaurants, cafes, bars, and other food service establishments

nodes.label: public healthcare management
nodes.description: Public administration and coordination of public health services

nodes.label: afforestation
nodes.description: establishment of a forest or stand of trees in an area where there was no previous tree cover

nodes.label: mixed farming
nodes.description: Mixed farming combines crop and animal production on the same farm.

nodes.label: third sector
nodes.description: Activities of national and sub-national non-profit organizations, charities, and voluntary groups.

nodes.label: risk
nodes.description: Risk is the potential for adverse consequences resulting from the dynamic interplay between (climate-related) hazards, exposure, and vulnerability of affected human or ecological systems.

nodes.label: tourism sector
nodes.description: Economic activity involving the travel and stay of individuals away from their usual place of residence for leisure, business, or other purposes

nodes.label: reforestation
nodes.description: natural or intentional restocking of existing forests and woodlands that have been depleted

nodes.label: nitrous oxide
nodes.description: Nitrous oxide is a greenhouse gas 300 times more potent than carbon dioxide (CO2) that remains in the atmosphere for more than 100 years.

nodes.label: emergency medical services
nodes.description: Immediate medical care and transportation provided in emergencies, often involving ambulances and trauma teams

nodes.label: non-timber forest sector
nodes.description: Collection and use of forest resources other than timber, such as fruits, nuts, medicinal plants, resins, and fibres

nodes.label: traditional medicine
nodes.description: Healthcare practices that involve traditional knowledge and complementary approaches such as herbal medicine

nodes.label: agricultural insurance
nodes.description: Insurance has become even more important as extreme weather events and climate change have increased the risks and uncertainties of farmers and agriculture-based enterprises, creating the need for agricultural insurance to protect from losses.

nodes.label: ecological justice
nodes.description: Concerning the balance between human communities and healthy ecosystems.

nodes.label: water management sector
nodes.description: This sector involves the distribution, treatment, and conservation of water resources.

nodes.label: hospitality sector
nodes.description: Activities that provide lodging, food, and entertainment services to guests, including hotels, restaurants, and resorts.

nodes.label: secondary healthcare system
nodes.description: specialised medical services provided by specialists or through referrals, typically in hospitals or clinics

nodes.label: high-risk occupations
nodes.description: People whose occupation makes them more likely to be adversely impacted by climate change.

nodes.label: forest protected area
nodes.description: Effective protection of tropical forests can reduce biodiversity loss and enhance carbon storage, as they are among the most biologically rich ecosystems on earth.

nodes.label: hydroelectric energy generation
nodes.description: generation of electricity using water as a renewable energy source, including hydropower plants and tidal energy systems

nodes.label: surface runoff
nodes.description: The draining of water (or substances carried in it) from the surface of an area of land

nodes.label: biodiversity loss
nodes.description: Increasing air and water temperatures and altered precipitation patterns are affecting the structure, composition and functions of ecosystems. Resulting in loss of biodiversity that help support human well-being.

nodes.label: informal workers
nodes.description: Informal workers do not have secure employment contracts, workers' benefits, social protection or workers' representation

nodes.label: coastal erosion
nodes.description: The erosion of the coast due to slow and sudden onset climate impacts

nodes.label: sustainable development goal 15
nodes.description: SDG15: life on land

nodes.label: sustainable agriculture
nodes.description: Farming that meets the needs of existing and future generations, while also ensuring profitability, environmental health and social and economic equity.

nodes.label: sustainable development goal 14
nodes.description: SDG14: life below water

nodes.label: water efficiency
nodes.description: efforts to reduce water waste and optimize water usage through efficient technologies, practices, and policies

nodes.label: plastic pollution impacts on wildlife and ecosystem health
nodes.description: Plastic pollution threatens wildlife and ecosystems. Large plastics trap marine animals, while microplastics interfere with biological functions of marine organisms.

nodes.label: glacial retreat
nodes.description: Glacial retreat is what happens when a glacier melts faster than new ice can build it back up. Directly related to increasing temperatures, it produces erosion, mudslides, flooding.

nodes.label: plastic consumption
nodes.description: This phase is centred around the use and maintenance of plastic products by consumers, and includes the plastic products that consumers are exposed to. This includes single-use products like plastic cups and plastic bags.

nodes.label: littering
nodes.description: The act of dropping rubbish on the ground in public places

nodes.label: illegal dumping
nodes.description: The illegal disposal of household, industrial, commercial or other ‘controlled’ waste

nodes.label: economic sector
nodes.description: Area of the economy in which actors engage in identical or related activities.

nodes.label: national trade
nodes.description: Exchange of goods and services within the borders of a country

nodes.label: ammonia
nodes.description: An inorganic compound of nitrogen and hydrogen produced industrially as a fertilizer and for many other uses

nodes.label: aquaculture
nodes.description: Cultivation of aquatic organisms such as fish, crustaceans, molluscs, and aquatic plants under controlled conditions, including freshwater and marine farming

nodes.label: sustainable development goal 6
nodes.description: SDG6: clean water and sanitation

nodes.label: exposed community
nodes.description: Communities that are significantly exposed to climate impacts due to their physical location

plastic pollution impacts on wildlife and ecosystem health

kg_data.query: Can you show me a bar chart of the percentiles of the different areas of deforestation?
